member.name: T:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDeviceScene
member.summary: Defines a device scene. A device scene may affect only the owning device or many devices in this device's ecosystem.
member.dev:
IMPORTANT: This interface intentionally defines an immutable object. In other words, there are no methods or property setters.
For ease of implementation and for thread-safety, we want to force consumers to go through the device capability itself and not each individual scene. If we allow editing through this interface, it makes device driver implementations more difficult as well as subsystem code (as subsystems would then have to wrap each property to ensure it is being called on that subsystem's thread).
The above statement appears as a dev-only comment because it is specific to the way we have implemented subsystems in our Tools.Runtime codebase.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDeviceScene.Id
member.summary:
ID of the scene (assigned by the device or its ecosystem).
Uniqueness is only guaranteed within the owning device. If the owning device is the primary controller of an entire ecosystem, this ID would be unique across all the devices provided by that ecosystem.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDeviceScene.Name
member.summary: Name of the scene (as configured using the device or its software).

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDeviceScene.SupportsIsActive
member.summary:
Indicates if the property is supported for this scene.
Depending on the device capabilities affected by a scene, some scenes may not be capable of providing feedback. This value can change if the device's scene is modified.
member.remarks: NOTE: The changed event appears on the owning device interface . This makes implementation easier and allows consumers of these interfaces to have context as to which device's scene changed.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDeviceScene.IsActive
member.summary: Indicates if this scene is currently active.
member.remarks: NOTE: The changed event appears on the owning device interface . This makes implementation easier and allows consumers of these interfaces to have context as to which device's scene changed.

member.name: T:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.ILocalizedDevice
member.summary:
Interface to be implemented by a device that implements one or more component interfaces that return strings that are intended to be displayed to the user and need to be localized.
Some component interfaces will return a string identifier that should then be resolved using this interface.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.ILocalizedDevice.GetSupportedCultures
member.summary: Retrieves all cultures supported by this device. See the method for more information about the format of each culture string.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.ILocalizedDevice.GetLocalizedStrings(System.String)
member.summary: Retrieves all the localized strings (and their IDs) used by this device.
member.param:
Specifies the language code and country region code to be retrieved. The string must formatted as the "languagecode2" as defined by the ISO 639-1 standard, followed by a hyphen and then the "country/regioncode2" as defined by the ISO 3166.
For example, "en-US" for English in the United States.
If the specified culture is not supported, this will return null.
member.para: Keys of 0 are not supported. Any property that returns 0 as a localized string ID indicates an empty string.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IFeedbackInformation.SupportsFeedback
member.summary: Indicates if the device supports feedback

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IFeedbackInformation.MinimumResponseTime
member.summary:
Approximate minimum number of milliseconds the device or driver will report state/feedback changes.
The formula for this value is typically: [Polling Interval (if any)] + [Device Response Time] + [Response Processing Time].
This may be 0 or a very small value if the device responds quickly and driver processing time is negligible.
Amongst other reasons, this property can be used to write smarter code that waits at least this amount of time before processing changes to provide optimize updates to higher level components.
If no capabilities of the device support feedback, this can be ignored.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IFeedbackInformation.MaximumResponseTime
member.summary:
Approximate maximum number of milliseconds the device or driver will take before reporting state/feedback changes after the device receives a command.
The formula for this value is typically: ([Device Response Time] + [Response Processing Time]) * 2 + [Polling Interval (if any)].
The first part of the equation is multiplied by 2 because a command may be sent to the device just as the driver is beginning a poll.
Amongst other reasons, this property can be used to write smarter code that waits at least this amount of time before timing out or declaring a device unresponsive.
If no capabilities of the device support feedback, this can be ignored.

member.name: T:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDriverInitialization
member.summary: Interface for drivers to implement if they require being initialized with persisted settings or additional files that were provided in the driver's pkg.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDriverInitialization.Initialize(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Allows the driver to initialize any local and external resources along with any custom settings.
member.param: Path to the folder containing all of the files from the pkg.
A serialized custom object containing settings specific to the driver. This object is created by the driver and stored by the consuming application on event.
member.returns: True if initialization succeeded, otherwise false.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDriverInitialization.DriverSettings
member.summary: Serialized custom object containing settings that are specific to this driver.

member.name: E:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDriverInitialization.DriverSettingsChanged
member.summary: Event indicating that the DriverSettings property has changed. The consuming application should store these settings and pass it back to the driver when calling the Initialize method.

member.name: T:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.ICloudReporting
member.summary:
Implemented by a driver to expose the ability to register with Crestron Cloud for device monitoring purposes, and to allow Crestron Cloud to control the driver.
A unique ID is required for this to operate.
The class ABasicDriver will handle all logic when using the class SimplSharpDeviceReporting.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.ICloudReporting.RegisterWithCloud(System.String)
member.summary: This must be invoked if the application desires the driver to report to the cloud. The driver will report any applicable feedback changes to the cloud, and it will allow the cloud to control the driver.
member.param: This must be a unique ID that is user-friendly. This must be between 1 and 256 characters

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.ICloudReporting.IsRegisteredWithCloud
member.summary: The current registration state of the driver with the cloud.

member.name: E:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.ICloudReporting.IsRegisteredWithCloudChanged
member.summary: Event for applications to use to find out when the registration status has changed, and if there was an error, what that error was.

member.name: T:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IPresetController
member.summary:
Interface to be implemented by a device which supports a list of presets (a.k.a. macros or scenes) that can be executed to change several aspects of one or more devices.
Each preset may affect only this device or many devices in this device's ecosystem.
member.remarks: See for more information about device capabilities.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IPresetController.GetPresets
member.summary: Gets the list of presets available on this device.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IPresetController.RecallPreset(System.String)
member.summary: Recalls/executes the preset with the specified ID (previously retrieved from the ).

member.name: E:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IPresetController.PresetsListChanged
member.summary:
Raised when the list of presets has changed.
Presumably, subscribers of this event will have called method once to retrieve a copy of the list. Based on the arguments of this event, the subscribers can then update their copy of the list without asking this device for the full list again (unless the event was a ; In that case, the full list would need to be retrieved again anyway).

member.name: E:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IPresetController.PresetStateChanged
member.summary: Raised when the state of a preset has changed.

member.name: T:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDevicePreset
member.summary: Defines a device preset (which sets one or more devices into a preconfigured state). A device preset may affect only the owning device or many devices in this device's ecosystem.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDevicePreset.Id
member.summary:
ID of the preset (assigned by the device or its ecosystem).
Uniqueness is only guaranteed within the owning device. If the owning device is the primary controller of an entire ecosystem, this ID would be unique across all the devices provided by that ecosystem.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDevicePreset.Name
member.summary:
Name of the preset (as configured using the device or its software).
Changes will be notified via the capability's event with the action .
member.remarks: NOTE: The changed event appears on the owning device interface . This makes device driver implementations easier and allows consumers of these interfaces to have context as to which device's preset changed.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDevicePreset.SupportsIsActive
member.summary:
Indicates if the property is supported for this preset.
Depending on the device capabilities affected by a preset, some presets may not be capable of providing feedback. This value can change if the device's preset is modified.
Changes will be notified via the capability's event with the action .
member.remarks: NOTE: The changed event appears on the owning device interface . This makes device driver implementations easier and allows consumers of these interfaces to have context as to which device's preset changed.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDevicePreset.IsActive
member.summary:
Indicates if this preset is currently active.
In other words, this is feedback from the device indicating that either all devices and properties affected by this preset are at their target values or that this was the last preset selected.
Changes will be notified via the capability's event .
member.remarks: NOTE: The changed event appears on the owning device interface . This makes device driver implementations easier and allows consumers of these interfaces to have context as to which device's preset changed.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDevicePreset.SupportsToggle
member.summary:
Indicates if calling while the preset is already active will act as a toggle.
Depending on the device capabilities/properties affected by a preset, it may not be capable of toggling or it may not make sense to support toggling. This value can change if the device's preset is modified.
Changes will be notified via the capability's event with the action .
member.remarks: NOTE: The changed event appears on the owning device interface . This makes device driver implementations easier and allows consumers of these interfaces to have context as to which device's preset changed.

member.summary: The communication direction of this port.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IPort.Name
member.summary: A friendly name for this port.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IPort.Id
member.summary: A unique ID for this port

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IPort.PassThruOnly
member.summary: Specifies if the virtual port is pass-thru only. If this is true, then it means there is no API control of this port and that the device's manual should be used to determine where the hardware connection goes to allow data to get to this port.

member.name: T:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IAudioVideoSwitchingCapabilities
member.summary: Defines the features needed for switching AV inputs and outputs

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IAudioVideoSwitchingCapabilities.GetRoutableOutputs
member.summary:
Returns the currently detected/set output extenders on the device that inputs returned by can be routed to using and/or . If the device does not support audio-breakaway, then both of those methods will perform the same function and throw their respective events.
Returns null if there is no option to route inputs to outputs

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IAudioVideoSwitchingCapabilities.GetRoutableInputs
member.summary: Returns the current detected/set input extenders on the device that can be routed to the outputs returned by using and/or . If the device does not support audio-breakaway, then both of those methods will perform the same function and throw their respective events.

member.summary:

To clear the route, specify null for the input.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IAudioVideoSwitchingCapabilities.RouteAudioInput(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Routes audio from the specified input to the specified output. This will route both audio and video if audio-breakaway is not support on the device.
To clear the route, specify null for the input.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IAudioVideoSwitchingCapabilities.SetOutputExtender(System.UInt32,Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IAudioVideoExtender)
member.summary:
This can be used to switch out defined outputs with a compatiable ones. For example, if a 3x1 HDMI switcher was going to be connected via HDMI1 to Output3, then the application should call this method updating the driver stating that HDMI1 is now a different extender.
If the driver can't detect HDBaseT extenders, then the application would use this to tell the driver which compatible extender is being used on the output.
member.param: Index being modified of the collection returned by .

member.name: T:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IAudioVideoExtender
member.summary:
An audio/video extender that could be a transmitter, a receiver, a card on the main AV switcher, or a switcher. Each extender can have physical connectors for transmitting/receive video/audio, it can have multiple ports for interacting with third-party devices connected to this extender, and it can have its own set of routable inputs/outputs.
Extenders will not allow switching locally unless returns or .
For flexibility, the virtual ports will be a part of the extender and not the nested audio/video inputs/outputs since the third-party API will be used to send data to specific locations and they could be used for any input/output.
No operations, including, can be done while the main AudioVideoSwitcher is in an off state if power feedback is supported.

This will return null when is or since it would be on the parent switcher device and not some connected extender.

member.name: T:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IConfigurableDevice
member.summary:
Represents a device that has a configuration
Pool controllers would be devices that have a configuration, because they can have multiple parts and pools that can be changed. Security system would also have a configuration because the sensors, zones, and alarms can be changed.
If a driver has a concept of a configuration, but there are reasons why it can't poll for this data either because there is too much polling, or there is too much parsing to do at the regular polling interval, then it must state that is false. Applications are then expected to call to get the latest configuration.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IConfigurableDevice.SupportsConfigurationUpdate
member.summary:
Indicates if the driver is able to detect configuration changes on the device.
This will be null if the feature is not applicable to a device. This will be true if the driver is able to detect configuration changes and will report the changes This will be false if the driver not able to detect configuration changes, and must be called to get the new configuration.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDeviceProperty.GetValue``1
member.summary:
Retrieves the value of this property.
If the requested type does not match the type referred to by , an will be thrown.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDeviceProperty.ParentPropertyKey
member.summary:
Used to associate this property with another property (in addition to any values that imply relationships).
For example, a device may define 2 properties, where the 1st property is a Boolean on-off switch, and the 2nd property has a render hint of which indicates the status of the device turning on. The 2nd property will refer the 1st property key here to indicate that it is associated with the 1st property.
Another example would be if a device had 2 sets of setpoints (i.e. 2 properties with and another 2 properties ). This key would indicate which target setpoint belongs with which actual setpoint (or vice-versa).
This may be null if the device only contains one set of associated properties. Using the above example, if a device only has one target and one actual setpoint property, the relationship is already implied by the render hint.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDeviceProperty.State
member.summary:
Indicates the state of this property. This may change based on the values of other properties.
Changes will be notified via the capability's event .

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDeviceProperty`1.AvailableValues
member.summary:
Available values for the property; The propertys value can only be set to one of these.
In addition to being the propertys value, each ID also refers to a localized string that is display name of this value. The localized string can be retrieved via the capability.
Also, based on the , this may also contain labels for each value defined by through . For example, if the value range is 0 to 3, this may define the labels for those values as "Off", "Slow", "Medium" and "Fast", respectively.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDeviceProperty`1.Value
member.summary:
Current value of this property.
Changes will be notified via the capability's event .
member.remarks: The changed event appears on the owning device interface . This makes device driver implementations easier and allows consumers of these interfaces to have context as to which device's property changed.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDeviceProperty`1.MinValue
member.summary: Minimum value allowed for numeric values; For strings, minimum length. Not applicable for all other non-numeric values.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDeviceProperty`1.MaxValue
member.summary: Maximum value allowed for numeric values; For strings, maximum length. Not applicable for all other non-numeric values.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDeviceProperty`1.StepSize
member.summary:
Amount to increment or decrement the value at a time; Applicable only when the refers to a numeric value.
If the type is or , this also defines the precision of the floating point value.
For example, if this value is 0.2, it would mean valid values could be 0, 0.2, 0.4, etc... Any invalid values passed to the method will be adjusted to the nearest valid value in the direction the value is being adjusted.

member.name: E:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IBasicPoolController.PoolsListChanged
member.summary:
Raised when the list of pools has changed.
Presumably, subscribers of this event will have called method once to retrieve a copy of the list of members. Based on the arguments of this event, the subscribers can then update their copy of the list without asking this device for the full list again (unless the event was a ; In that case, the full list would need to be retrieved again anyway).

member.name: E:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IBasicPoolController.NonPoolPartsListChanged
member.summary:
Raised when the list of non-pool-parts has changed.
Presumably, subscribers of this event will have called the method once to retrieve a copy of the list. Based on the arguments of this event, the subscribers can then update their copy of the list without asking this device for the full list again (unless the event was a ; In that case, the full list would need to be retrieved again anyway).

member.summary: Defines one available value for use with an instance.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDevicePropertyAvailableValue.GetValue``1
member.summary:
Retrieves the value of this property.
If the requested type does not match the type referred to by , an will be thrown.
The only other allowed type is "object", with the caveat that it will cause value types to be boxed.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDevicePropertyAvailableValue.LocalizedCategoryNameId
member.summary:
ID referring to the localized name of the category to which this property value belongs; This will be 0 if this value does not belong to any category.
This ID should not be persisted by any consuming code. It is only for display/categorization purposes for the current instance of the running program/app.
When "available values" are intended to be displayed with other similar "available values", they will all have the same category name. For example, if this value is the color "Red", this category name may be "Primary Colors". There may be another value named "Purple" and its category name would be "Secondary Colors".
When displaying a mix of categorized and uncategorized values, it is recommended that the uncategorized values be shown last, possibly in their own category named "Uncategorized" or "Other", for example.
member.remarks: This localized string can be retrieved from the device via the interface .

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IDevicePropertyAvailableValue.LocalizedNameId
member.summary: ID referring to the localized display name of this property value.
member.remarks: This localized string can be retrieved from the device via the interface .

member.summary: The underlying property value to be set when this available value is chosen.

member.summary: Indicates the property is intended to be displayed as on/off switch.

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.Enums.DevicePropertyRenderHint.OnOffValues
member.summary:
Indicates the property is an additional value that can be set, in addition to an associated property whose render hint is .
In other words, there will be 2 properties. One will be the property that turns on/off the device feature. The other will be the one that configures that device feature.
For example, turning on a strobe light may offer a preset list of flashing patterns to choose from. The intention here is that a user interface might want to show the 2 properties closely coupled together. This propertys will be populated.

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.Enums.DevicePropertyRenderHint.SetpointTarget
member.summary: Indicates the property is intended to be displayed as range of values the user can target, for example, as a slider or a numeric spinner.

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.Enums.DevicePropertyRenderHint.SetpointActual
member.summary: Indicates the property is intended to be displayed as the actual/current value when there is another property with the hint of .

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.Enums.DevicePropertyRenderHint.Slider
member.summary:
Indicates the property is intended to be displayed as slider or similar control.
How exactly the slider is rendered can vary depending on the number of values specified by the range and and the between them.
The should also be factored in when rendering the slider.
If the is populated, it indicates custom labels from the device for each value (e.g. Slow, Medium, Fast).

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.Enums.DevicePropertyRenderHint.Status
member.summary:
Indicates the property is the status of an associated property.
For example, turning on pump may require a "priming" phase. One property would exist to turn the pump on/off. Another property with this render hint and the appropriate would have a value of "Priming" while the pump is turning on.
The intention here is that a user interface might want to show the 2 properties closely coupled together since one is the status of the other.

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.Enums.AudioVideoExtenderType.IndirectOutput

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.Enums.AudioVideoExtenderType.IndirectInputWithSwitching
member.summary:
An input that has switching capabilities of its own and they are a feature of the API. If a transmitter has multiple inputs/outputs on it, but the API does not expose a way to switch between the inputs, then this type should not be used - use .
Has switching capabilities.

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.Enums.AudioVideoExtenderType.IndirectOutputWithSwitching
member.summary:
An output that has switching capabilities of its own and they are a feature of the API. If a receiver has multiple inputs/outputs on it, but the API does not expose a way to switch between the inputs, then this type should not be used - use .
Has switching capabilities.

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.Enums.DevicePropertyStates.Disabled
member.summary:
Indicates if the property is currently disabled.
This may change based on the values of other properties. For example, changing the value of one property may disable another property.

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.Enums.DevicePropertyStates.ValueNotAvailable
member.summary:
Indicates if the value of the property is not currently available.
In other words, the device may not have the value yet or the device is not capable of retrieving the value (for example, if a temperature sensor is not connected).
When this flag is present, the value returned by or must be ignored.

member.summary:

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Communication.StopBits
member.summary:

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Communication.Port
member.summary:
The ethernet port used for communication
If this driver is not using ethernet for communication, this should be set to 0.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Communication.EnableAutoPolling
member.summary:
Specifies if the driver should poll automatically.
If this is set to false, then the driver will not poll unless the driver sets to true.
This should be set to true even if is set to true. This allows the driver to poll at least once to get initial states.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Communication.EnableAutoReconnect
member.summary:
Specifies if the driver should reconnect to a device automatically if there was a disconnect.
This is not used if the driver uses the COM port.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Communication.TimeBetweenCommands
member.summary:
Specifies the amount of time in ms to wait in between sending commands.
This value must be greater than 0 and a multiple of 250. If it is not, it will be automatically quantized to be a multiple of 250. Example: A value of 200 will be treated as 250 internally and a a value of 251 will be treated as 500 internally.
If the driver wishes to specify a value less than 250, then it should set .

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Communication.TimeBetweenCommandsOverride
member.summary:
Specifies the amount of time in ms to wait in between sending commands.
If this is not null, this will be used instead of .
This value may be 0 and must be a multiple of 25.
This value should only be set in the driver's embedded JSON file and should not be referenced by the driver.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Communication.ResponseTimeout
member.summary: Specifies the amount of time in ms to wait before considering a polling command to be timed out.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Communication.WaitForResponse
member.summary: Specifies if the driver should wait for a response to a previous command before sending another command. This is tracked using when it returns with set to true.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Communication.IpProtocol
member.summary:
Specifies the protocol used for ethernet communication.
This should be set to NotSpecified if the driver doesn't use ethernet for communication.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Communication.IsUserAdjustable
member.summary:
Specifies if there are any values in the Communciation node that can be modified.
This is used by applications to potentially allow users to change the baud rate and other settings. Applications will look at to find which properties can be changed.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Communication.Authentication
member.summary:
Specifies any authentication settings for communciation with the device.
This is referring to APIs that require the driver to send a username and/or password.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Communication.IsSecure

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.DatFileAudioVideoSwitcher.msBetweenRouteCommands
member.summary:
Specifies the amount of time in milliseconds to wait before sending another route command. Example: If an IR driver requires IN_1 to be sent, and then OUT_1 to be sent in order to route the first input to the first output, then this value would be set to the time between the IN_1 and OUT_1 commands being sent.
This is only used for IR drivers.

member.name: T:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABasicDriver
member.summary:
The abstract class that represent all drivers. It provides a default implementation of the following component interfaces:
IBasicInformation, IConnection2, IBasicLogger, IBasicInformation2, IDisposable, ISupportedCommandsHelper, and IModelFileSupport.
Drivers should not override anything here and should instead override the protocol class unless specified otherwise.

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABasicDriver.Logger
member.summary: A logger object that should not be referenced within drivers. This was introduced for more logging levels in the framework.

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABasicDriver.ConnectionTransport
member.summary:
The transport used for communication with the device which is responsible for transmitting and receiving messages.
This should be set within the driver's constructor to a class that inmplements ATransportDriver.
[[[example]]]

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABasicDriver.DriverData
member.summary:
The common driver data between all device types. This will be set automatically by ConvertJsonFileToDriverData in each device-type library.
This should not be used or referenced - use the following instead:
Display - DisplayData
Cable Box - CableBoxData
Video Server - VideoServerData
Bluray Player - BlurayPlayerData
AV Receiver - AvrData

This should be called last when destroying a driver.

member.summary:
This will disconnect the driver from the device, if supported.
Driver developers - this will call ConnectionTransport.Stop()

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABasicDriver.Reconnect
member.summary:
This will disconnect the driver from the device and then connect to it, if supported.
Driver developers - this will call ConnectionTransport.Stop() then ConnectionTransport.Start()

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABasicDriver.Connect
member.summary:
This will connect the driver to the device, if supported.
Driver developers - this will call ConnectionTransport.Start()

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABasicDriver.OverrideUsername(System.String)
member.summary:
Allows applications to set the username the driver should use when authenticating with the device. This can be set before or after initializing and connecting the driver. If a UsernameKey is supplied, then this value will not be used unless there is no username in CrestronDataStore.
Driver developers - this must be implemented in the driver if the driver supports authentication with the device.
member.param: The username to use for authentication with the device.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABasicDriver.OverridePassword(System.String)
member.summary:
Allows applications to set the password the driver should use when authenticating with the device. This can be set before or after initializing and connecting the driver. If a PasswordKey is supplied, then this value will not be used unless there is no password in CrestronDataStore.
Driver developers - this must be implemented in the driver if the driver supports authentication with the device.
member.param: The username to use for authentication with the device.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABasicDriver.GetLocalizedStrings(System.String)
member.summary: Retrieves all the localized strings (and their IDs) used by this device.
member.param:
Specifies the language code and country region code to be retrieved. The string must formatted as the "languagecode2" as defined by the ISO 639-1 standard, followed by a hyphen and then the "country/regioncode2" as defined by the ISO 3166.
For example, "en-US" for English in the United States.
If the specified culture is not supported, this will return null.
member.para: Keys of 0 are not supported. Any property that returns 0 as a localized string ID indicates an empty string.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABasicDriver.GetSupportedCultures
member.summary: Retrieves all cultures supported by this device. See the method for more information about the format of each culture string.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABasicDriver.SaveSetting(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary:
Save a setting for this device by key which will be persisted through reboots and power loss.
This can be useful for devices that don't remember their own settings or can be used to return a device to its previous state after a power failure/reboot/etc.
To retreive the value of the setting use .

member.summary: Erase the value of a saved setting from memory.

member.summary: Get the value of a setting that has been saved.
member.returns: The value of the setting. Null if the key is not found.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABasicDriver.RegisterWithCloud(System.String)
member.summary: This must be invoked if the application desires the driver to report to the cloud. The driver will report any applicable feedback changes to the cloud, and it will allow the cloud to control the driver.
member.param: This must be a unique ID that is user-friendly. This must be between 1 and 256 characters
member.returns: True if registration was successful.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABasicDriver.FakeFeedbackController
member.summary: Used by the framework to fake-feedback for device-types that use one StateChange event with an enum that specifies the change. This will be instantiated when the driver's embedded JSON is deseriaized if SupportsFeedback is true. It only fakes feedback at this level, and not the protocol level. It does this by preventing events via StateChange from executing if that event is being faked. The controller will stop blocking events once true feedback matches the faked state.

member.summary:
Specifies the driver is currently connected to the device.
Ethernet driver will set this to true when the socket state is OK.
HTTP drivers will set this to true when communication is possible with the device.
COM and CEC drivers will set this value if they receive any data from the device.
IR drivers will not set this to true.

CrestronSerialDeviceApi.DeviceSupport

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABasicDriver.MinimumResponseTime
member.summary:
Approximate minimum number of milliseconds the device or driver will report state/feedback changes.
The formula for this value is typically: [Polling Interval (if any)] + [Device Response Time] + [Response Processing Time].
This may be 0 or a very small value if the device responds quickly and driver processing time is negligible.
Amongst other reasons, this property can be used to write smarter code that waits at least this amount of time before processing changes to provide optimize updates to higher level components.
If no capabilities of the device support feedback, this can be ignored.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABasicDriver.MaximumResponseTime
member.summary:
Approximate maximum number of milliseconds the device or driver will take before reporting state/feedback changes after the device receives a command.
The formula for this value is typically: ([Device Response Time] + [Response Processing Time]) * 2 + [Polling Interval (if any)].
The first part of the equation is multiplied by 2 because a command may be sent to the device just as the driver is beginning a poll.
Amongst other reasons, this property can be used to write smarter code that waits at least this amount of time before timing out or declaring a device unresponsive.
If no capabilities of the device support feedback, this can be ignored.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABaseDriverProtocol.Send(Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.CommandSet)
member.summary:
Sends the specified CommandSet object to the internal command processor.
If this is a standard polling command, it will be sent to the polling queue as non-persistent. Otherwise it will be sent to the non-polling queue or will be sent to the device immediatly if conditions allow that.
member.returns: False

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABaseDriverProtocol.PrepareStringThenSend(Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.CommandSet)
member.summary:
Marks a command as ready to send (no further processing is neeed). This will then invoke Send with the commandSet.
This should be overridden by drivers to modify the CommandSet before it is ready to be sent to the device.
If a driver sends the data directly to the device in this method, that driver needs to return true in their overridden method.
member.param: The command to get ready to set
member.returns: True if this method sent the command to the device by the driver.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABaseDriverProtocol.SetPollingSequence(Crestron.RAD.Common.Enums.StandardCommandsEnum[])
member.summary: Sets the polling sequence the driver should use while the device is powered on. Polling commands will be prepared when they are about to be sent and unprepared afterwards. Only standard polling commands are allowed in the sequence.
member.param: The standard polling commands that should be added to the polling queue

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABaseDriverProtocol.AddPollingCommand(Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.CommandSet)
member.summary:
Do not call this in a driver. Only called by the device-type classes. Given a CommandSet, this will convert it to and make it a non-standard polling command even if the CommandSet is already a polling command.
This allows the framework to still add non-standard polling commands to the polling queue while preventing drivers from doing the same thing. Drivers need to override Poll() to perform non-standard polling.
This will not add the command if is null/empty.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABaseDriverProtocol.CanRemoveNonPollingCommandOverride(Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.CommandSet,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Defines the rules for determining if a non-polling command can be removed from the queue.
member.param: The command that is being questioned
True if there is a PowerOn command in the queue
member.returns: True if the command can be removed

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABaseDriverProtocol.CanSendCommand(Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.CommandSet)
member.summary: Method to determine if a command can be sent, bypassing the command queue This method should be overridden in the SDK for devices for more specific rules to be applied
member.param: commandSet to evaluate if command can be sent
member.returns: True if successful

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABaseDriverProtocol.CanQueueCommand(Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.CommandSet,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Method to determine if a command can be queued This method should be overridden in the SDK for devices for more specific rules to be applied
member.param: commandSet to evaluate if command can be queued
member.returns: True if successful

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.ABaseDriverProtocol.ConnectionChanged(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
This is invoked whenever the connection state changes, either via the transport class or there being too many time-outs in this class.
The base method must be called if this is overridden unless the driver sees a need for hiding connected/disconnected feedback, such as in cases where it can be predicted. Example: Device shuts off LAN port for a few seconds when it is powered on initially.
For drivers that set SupportsUnsolicitedFeedback to true, this will restart the polling sequence if the connection state when from false to true

member.summary: Invoked when a poll command that was recently sent has not received a response in at least ResponeTimeOut ms. If there are five or more timeouts, this will invoked ConnectionChangedEvent with a disconnected state if the transport.IsEthernetTransport is set to false.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.Api.SupportsConfigurationUpdate
member.summary:
Indicates if the driver is able to detect configuration changes on the device.
This will be null if the feature is not applicable to a device. This will be true if the driver is able to detect configuration changes and will report the changes This will be false if the driver not able to detect configuration changes, and must be called to get the new configuration.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.Feedback.SupportsUnsolicitedFeedback
member.summary: Lets a driver define if the API supports providing updates without polling. If this is enabled, then the driver's polling sequence will only be sent until each individual poll command receives a response. The driver will poll again like this if the connection state goes from false to true.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.Feedback.ConnectedStatePollCommand
member.summary:
The command a driver should send using the polling interval to illicit a response from the device. This can be any command that causes no operation to be performed on the device such as a power poll. This must be used if the driver does not use an ethernet transport to keep track of disconnects.
This is only used when is set to true.

member.summary: Retrieves the UI definition for this device.
member.returns: A string value containing the xml used to define the custom user interface for this device.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.ExtensionDevice.IExtensionDevice.GetSupportedCultures
member.summary:
Retrieves all cultues supported by this device.
The format of the returned strings are "languagecode2-country/regioncode2" as defined by the ISO 639-1 standard and the ISO 3166 standard.
For example, "en-US" for English in the United States.
member.returns: A list of cultures.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.ExtensionDevice.IExtensionDevice.GetLanguageTranslations(System.String)
member.summary: Retrieves all the translated strings used by this device for the provided culture.
member.param:
Specifies the language code and country region code to be retrieved. The string must formatted as the "languagecode2" as defined by the ISO 639-1 standard, followed by a hyphen and then the "country/regioncode2" as defined by the ISO 3166 standard.
For example, "en-US" for English in the United States.
If the specified culture is not supported, this will return English, and if English is not supported then this will return the first language that is found in the driver. If there are no language translations then this will return null.

member.summary: Arguments for events that refer to a list changing.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Events.ListChangedEventArgs`1.ChangedAction
member.summary: The action that caused this event.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Events.ListChangedEventArgs`1.OldItem
member.summary: Item that was removed or replaced.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Events.ListChangedEventArgs`1.NewItem
member.summary: Item that was added.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.Events.ListChangedEventArgs`1.Index
member.summary:
Index of the or .
For added item events, this is then current index of the item. For removed item events, this is the index from which the item was removed. For replace events, this is the index of the item being replaced (and therefore the incoming item, too). For reset events, this will be -1.

member.name: T:Crestron.RAD.Common.Events.ListChangedAction
member.summary: Describes the action that caused an applicable list changed event.

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.Events.ListChangedAction.Added
member.summary: An item was added to a list.

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.Events.ListChangedAction.Removed
member.summary:
An item was removed from a list.
NOTE: During this "Removed" changed action, the item being removed may not be fully functional. However, it will be identifiable. For example, if it has an ID or a Name property, they will still be valid, but a method such as SetValue() or a property such as CurrentValue will not be valid and may even cause an error if called/accessed during this "Removed" action.

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.Events.ListChangedAction.Replaced
member.summary:
An item in a list was replaced with another item.
If the old and new items are the same reference, it means one or more parts of the object changed and all data based on that object should be refreshed.

member.name: F:Crestron.RAD.Common.Events.ListChangedAction.Reset
member.summary: The content of the list has been cleared or has changed significantly. Subscribers to event being raised should request a new copy of the list from the object that raised the event.

The protocol is where all commands are built, and where responses are handled.

member.summary: Loads the configuration for the switcher and sets the routable/compatible inputs/outputs, adds all defined polling commands to the queue for the switcher and extenders.

member.summary:

This can be overriden in the driver, but the base call must be made.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.DeviceTypes.AudioVideoSwitcher.AAudioVideoSwitcherProtocol.ConnectionChangedEvent(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Method to capture connection change events from .
Drivers can override this to perform custom actions based on the connection state changing. The base method should still be called to ensure the application gets the event and that is properly set.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.DeviceTypes.AudioVideoSwitcher.AAudioVideoSwitcherProtocol.ResponseValidator(System.String,Crestron.RAD.Common.Enums.CommonCommandGroupType)
member.summary:
Validates the received data is a properly formatted and handled response, sets the command group based on what is contained in , and sets to true.
This will attempt to gather responses based on the delimiter specified in .
This will check for all AV Switcher feedback headers, and then it will loop through the extenders if nothing matched the switcher first.
member.param:
The data the driver has received so far.
If or is not set to true, then the next call to this method will contain the previous response and whatever new data has been received since. There is logic in the framework to clear this buffer if a response is not validated within the value specified by .

The command group of the last sent to the device. To get more information on the , reference .
This is useful when is true and there is no context to responses.
member.returns: Instance of ValidatedRxData that is ready to be processed by the internal receiving logic.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.DeviceTypes.AudioVideoSwitcher.AAudioVideoSwitcherProtocol.RouteVideoInput(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
See .
This method will look through the data contained in the embedded JSON-formatted file and retrieve the correct API identifier for each extender. This will replace the string "{input}" with that input's API identifier, and the same will be done with "{output}". This will match the extenders by ID.
Drivers must override this if the API command built differs from the standard implementation.
Default logic assumes there is no audio-breakaway supported. If it is and different API commands are used for the different routes, then the method must be overriden and build the independent commands manually.

Default logic assumes there is no audio-breakaway supported. If it is and different API commands are used for the different routes, then the method must be overriden and build the independent commands manually.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.DeviceTypes.AudioVideoSwitcher.AAudioVideoSwitcherProtocol.GetRoutableOutputs
member.summary:
See .
Drivers can modify this collection using the method .
This collection is initially set to the contents of the embedded JSON-formatted file and does not need to be changed unless the application modifies the collection.
This may be overriden if the driver developer is handling the routable input/output collections in their driver.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.DeviceTypes.AudioVideoSwitcher.AAudioVideoSwitcherProtocol.GetRoutableInputs
member.summary:
See .
Drivers can modify this collection using the method .
This collection is initially set to the contents of the embedded JSON-formatted file and does not need to be changed unless the application modifies the collection or the driver needs to. All ListChanged events are handled internally.
This may be overriden if the driver developer is handling the routable input/output collections in their driver.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.DeviceTypes.AudioVideoSwitcher.AAudioVideoSwitcherProtocol.SetOutputExtender(System.UInt32,Crestron.RAD.Common.Interfaces.IAudioVideoExtender)
member.summary:
See .
Drivers can use this to set the extenders if they can detect changes on their own. In these cases must be set to true otherwise applications may ignore the changes.
When this class is initialized, the extender configuration specified in the embedded JSON-formatted file will be used.
The initial configuration determines the maximum number of inputs and outputs.
This may be overriden if the driver developer is handling the routable input/output collections in their driver.

Drivers can use this to set the extenders if they can detect changes on their own. In these cases must be set to true otherwise applications may ignore the changes.
When this class is initialized, the extender configuration specified in the embedded JSON-formatted file will be used.
This may be overriden if the driver developer is handling the routable input/output collections in their driver.

member.summary: The ramping timers due times based on how many times the timer rolled over. Any tick after the fourth will be set to the initial ramping rate.

member.summary: Represents the first time the timer callback was invoked

member.summary: Represents the second time the timer callback was invoked

member.summary: Represents all other times the callback is invoked

member.summary: Constructor

member.summary: Invokes PerformActionOnDevice then starts the ramping process

member.summary: Stops the timer without invoking the callback

member.summary: Implementation of IDisposeable

member.summary: The callback invoke by the CTimer instance

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.Ramping.ARampingTimer.PerformActionOnDevice
member.summary: The action that needs to be performed on the device when the ramping timer has invoked the callback or when the timer is initially started, the action will be performed immediatly and then the timer will start with a due time of RampingRate.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.Ramping.ARampingTimer.RampingRate
member.summary: This will initially be set to either 250ms if TimeBetweenCommandsOverride is null or it will be set to TimeBetweenCommandsOverride but will be clamped to 100ms. This value will change the longer the ramp lasts.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.Common.BasicDriver.Ramping.ARampingTimer.Ramping
member.summary: Used to let the main framework know if the timer is ramping, but doesn't let them set the state

member.summary: Used for ramping when we have one method to invoke with a paramter for the direction

member.summary: Used for ramping when we have one method that needs to be invoke at the ramping interval

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.DeviceTypes.ExtensionDevice.AExtensionDevice.GetUiDefinition(System.String)
member.summary:
Gets the ui definition for the driver.
The default implementation of this method assumes there is only one ui definition. If more than one exists, this method can be overridden to provide additional logic to determine which ui definition to return. It can also be overridden to ignore the folderPath and simply return a static or dynamic string from the driver itself.
member.param: The path to the ui definitions folder.
member.returns: The contents of the ui definition file as a string.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.DeviceTypes.ExtensionDevice.AExtensionDevice.GetSupportedCultures(System.String)
member.summary:
Get the supported cultures for the driver.
The default implementation of this method uses the names of the translation files provided in the "Translations" folder of the driver's pkg. This method can be overridden to provide custom logic to determine what the supported cultures are.
member.param: The path to the translations folder.
member.returns:
All cultues supported by this device.
The format of the returned strings are "languagecode2-country/regioncode2" as defined by the ISO 639-1 standard and the ISO 3166 standard.
For example, "en-US" for English in the United States.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.DeviceTypes.ExtensionDevice.AExtensionDevice.GetLanguageTranslations(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Get the language translations for the provided culture.
The default implementation of this method finds the translation file in the "Translations" folder of the driver's pkg that matches the provided culture and returns the translations dictionary provided in that file. This method can be overridden to provide custom logic to determine what translations should be returned.
member.param: The path to the translations folder.
The requested culture. Example: "en-US" for English in the United States.
member.returns: A Dictionary of translations where the key is and the value is the translated string.

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.ExtensionMethods.ExtensionMethods.RegisterInterface``2(RADCommon.Interfaces.IInterfaceLookup{``1},``0)
member.summary: Extension method to expose a generic API to register an interface on an IInterfaceLookup. Note that this is going to use typeof(T) to get the interface, not implementation.GetType() to avoid hard-to-predict results. This does mean, though, that if you call this with an instance of "object" it's not going to register anything since typeof(object) isn't going to have any interfaces that implement TBaseInterface. Use this API when you have an object that's already typed as the type you want to register.
member.typeparam: The type to register
The base interface type of the lookup (usually ICapability)
member.param: The object implementing the interface T to register

member.name: M:Crestron.RAD.Common.ExtensionMethods.ExtensionMethods.TryGetInterface``2(RADCommon.Interfaces.IInterfaceLookup{``1})
member.summary: Extension method to get an interface from an IInterfaceLookup and cast it to the desired type. This method works for any type of IInterfaceLookup but requires specifying the TBaseInterface for the syntax to work.
member.typeparam: The interface to look up
The base interface of the IInterfaceLookup
member.returns: An instance of T, or null if not found

member.name: F:System.Runtime.Serialization.Formatters.FormatterAssemblyStyle.Simple
member.summary: In simple mode, the assembly used during deserialization need not match exactly the assembly used during serialization. Specifically, the version numbers need not match as the Overload:System.Reflection.Assembly.LoadWithPartialName method is used to load the assembly.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.Serialization.Formatters.FormatterAssemblyStyle.Full
member.summary: In full mode, the assembly used during deserialization must match exactly the assembly used during serialization. The Overload:System.Reflection.Assembly.Load method of the System.Reflection.Assembly class is used to load the assembly.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContextStates
member.summary: Defines a set of flags that specifies the source or destination context for the stream during serialization.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContextStates.CrossProcess
member.summary: Specifies that the source or destination context is a different process on the same computer.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContextStates.CrossMachine
member.summary: Specifies that the source or destination context is a different computer.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContextStates.File
member.summary: Specifies that the source or destination context is a file. Users can assume that files will last longer than the process that created them and not serialize objects in such a way that deserialization will require accessing any data from the current process.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContextStates.Persistence
member.summary: Specifies that the source or destination context is a persisted store, which could include databases, files, or other backing stores. Users can assume that persisted data will last longer than the process that created the data and not serialize objects so that deserialization will require accessing any data from the current process.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContextStates.Remoting
member.summary: Specifies that the data is remoted to a context in an unknown location. Users cannot make any assumptions whether this is on the same computer.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContextStates.Other
member.summary: Specifies that the serialization context is unknown.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContextStates.Clone
member.summary: Specifies that the object graph is being cloned. Users can assume that the cloned graph will continue to exist within the same process and be safe to access handles or other references to unmanaged resources.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContextStates.CrossAppDomain
member.summary: Specifies that the source or destination context is a different AppDomain.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContextStates.All
member.summary: Specifies that the serialized data can be transmitted to or received from any of the other contexts.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext
member.summary: Describes the source and destination of a given serialized stream, and provides an additional caller-defined context.

member.name: M:System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext.#ctor(System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContextStates)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the StreamingContext class with a given context state.
member.param: A bitwise combination of the values that specify the source or destination context for this .

member.name: M:System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext.#ctor(System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContextStates,System.Object)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the StreamingContext class with a given context state, and some additional information.
member.param: A bitwise combination of the values that specify the source or destination context for this .

Any additional information to be associated with the . This information is available to any object that implements ISerializable or any serialization surrogate. Most users do not need to set this parameter.

member.summary: Determines whether two StreamingContext instances contain the same values.

member.summary: Returns a hash code of this object.

member.summary: Gets context specified as part of the additional context.

member.summary: Appends information to the provided operation and descriptor to include details about how to gather a value for method parameter. Both back-end parameter information and UI prompting information must be given.
member.param: Must be an ACTION type operation obtained from a CreateAction call.
Must be a method call descriptor from having called AddMethodCall
.NET type of the method parameter being processed
The name of the parameter as defined in a .Net ParameterInfo object
A unique key for the UI prompt portion. If an existing key is used then the same prompt will be used for the newly added parameter.
Localization key for the prompt text. Optional if the prompt exists since the value won't be used.
Attributes for the prompt, see the source enum. Optional if the prompt exists since the value won't be used.
The style of UI control to use for the data type. Optional if the prompt exists since the value won't be used.
The value units of the prompt. Optional if the prompt exists since the value won't be used.
Parent key that the a new prompt will belong to. Optional if the prompt exists since the value won't be used.
The minimum value relative to the selected prompt value type. Optional if the prompt exists since the value won't be used.
The maximum value relative to the selected prompt value type. Optional if the prompt exists since the value won't be used.
For numeric types, a step value to control increments of the collected value. Optional if the prompt exists since the value won't be used.
The default value relative to the selected prompt value type. Optional if the prompt exists since the value won't be used.
Provides specific values to choose from vs. free-form or ranged value entry. Optional if the prompt exists since the value won't be used.
For decoupling the parameter type from the prompt type.

The to use to get dynamic available values (values not known at compile time) from the device. The member name of the descriptor must return an enumerable. This parameter is optional. If available values are known at compile time, use the parameter instead.
The to use to get the id of the available value. This parameter is optional. If the id of the available parameter is retrieved directly from the this parameter is not needed.
The to use to get the display name of the available value. This parameter is optional. If the display name of the available parameter is retrieved directly from the this parameter is not needed.

member.summary: Hint for user interfaces as to the intended usage of this device property.

member.name: P:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.IDeviceProperty.State
member.summary:
Indicates the state of this property. This may change based on the values of other properties.
Changes will be notified via the capability's event .
member.remarks: NOTE: The changed event appears on the owning device interface . This makes device driver implementations easier and allows consumers of these interfaces to have context as to which device's preset changed.

member.name: P:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.IDeviceProperty.ParentPropertyKey
member.summary:
Used to associate this property with another property (in addition to any values that imply relationships).
For example, a device may define 2 properties, where the 1st property is a Boolean on-off switch, and the 2nd property has a render hint of which indicates the status of the device turning on. The 2nd property will refer the 1st property key here to indicate that it is associated with the 1st property.
Another example would be if a device had 2 sets of setpoints (i.e. 2 properties with and another 2 properties ). This key would indicate which target setpoint belongs with which actual setpoint (or vice-versa).
This may be null if the device only contains one set of associated properties. Using the above example, if a device only has one target and one actual setpoint property, the relationship is already implied by the render hint.

member.summary:
Defines one available value for use with an instance.
This object is immutable as it is essentially a constant.

member.summary: The underlying property value to be set when this available value is chosen.

member.name: P:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.IDevicePropertyAvailableValue.LocalizedCategoryNameId
member.summary:
ID referring to the localized name of the category to which this property value belongs; This will be 0 if this value does not belong to any category.
This ID should not be persisted by any consuming code. It is only for display/categorization purposes for the current instance of the running program/app.
When "available values" are intended to be displayed with other similar "available values", they will all have the same category name. For example, if this value is the color "Red", this category name may be "Primary Colors". There may be another value named "Purple" and its category name would be "Secondary Colors".
When displaying a mix of categorized and uncategorized values, it is recommended that the uncategorized values be shown last, possibly in their own category named "Uncategorized" or "Other", for example.
member.remarks: This localized string can be retrieved from the device via the interface .

member.summary: ID referring to the localized display name of this property value.
member.remarks: This localized string can be retrieved from the device via the interface .

member.summary: Defines a device property's value and other property-type-specific information.
member.dev:
IMPORTANT: This interface intentionally defines an read-only object. In other words, there are no methods or property setters.
For ease of implementation and for thread-safety, we want to force property editors to go through the device capability itself and not each individual property. If we allow editing through this interface, it makes device driver implementations more difficult as well as subsystem code (as subsystems would then have to wrap each property to ensure it is being called on that subsystem's thread).
The above statement appears as a dev-only comment because it is specific to the way we have implemented subsystems in our Tools.Runtime codebase.

member.name: P:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.IDeviceProperty`1.Value
member.summary:
Current value of this property.
Changes will be notified via the capability's event .
member.remarks: The changed event appears on the owning device interface . This makes device driver implementations easier and allows consumers of these interfaces to have context as to which device's property changed.

member.name: P:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.IDeviceProperty`1.MinValue
member.summary: Minimum value allowed for numeric values; For strings, minimum length. Not applicable for all other non-numeric values.

member.name: P:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.IDeviceProperty`1.MaxValue
member.summary: Maximum value allowed for numeric values; For strings, maximum length. Not applicable for all other non-numeric values.

member.name: P:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.IDeviceProperty`1.StepSize
member.summary:
Amount to increment or decrement the value at a time; Applicable only when the refers to a numeric value.
If the type is or , this also defines the precision of the floating point value.
For example, if this value is 0.2, it would mean valid values could be 0, 0.2, 0.4, etc... Any invalid values passed to the method will be adjusted to the nearest valid value in the direction the value is being adjusted.

member.name: P:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.IDeviceProperty`1.AvailableValues
member.summary:
Available values for the property; Null if not applicable.
The propertys value can only be set to one of these object's .
This may also contain labels for each value defined by through . For example, if the value range is 0 to 3, this may define the labels for those values as "Off", "Slow", "Medium" and "Fast", respectively.

member.name: T:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyAttributes
member.summary: Defines additional information about a device property; Specified by the interface property .

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyAttributes.None
member.summary: Indicates the property has no additional attributes; It is a read-write property with no limits other than those imposed by the .

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyAttributes.ReadOnly
member.summary: Indicates the property is read-only and its value cannot be set. Only the device itself can change the value and report changes via the event.

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyAttributes.MinValue
F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyAttributes.MaxValue
F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyAttributes.StepSize

members.member: Indicates the property's value should be included in summaries or descriptions in order to provide better context about its purpose.

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyAttributes.Optional
member.summary: Indicates that the system should use the default value when no explicit value is collected

member.name: T:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyType
member.summary: Defines the possible types of a device property; Specified by the interface property .

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyType.LocalizedString
member.summary:
Indicates the type is a localized string that must be resolved using the interface.
The actual value of this property will be equivalent to . That integer then needs to be looked up in the key-value pairs returned by .

member.name: T:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyUnit
member.summary: Defines the possible units of measurement of a device property; Specified by the interface property .

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyUnit.None
member.summary: Indicates that units are not applicable or not known.

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyUnit.Celsius
member.summary: Measures whole degrees in Celsius.

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyUnit.Fahrenheit
member.summary: Measures whole degrees in Fahrenheit.

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyUnit.Percentage
member.summary: Measures a percentage, typically between 0 and 100, but the minimum and maximum may vary depending on the .

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyUnit.Millivolts
member.summary: Measures 1/1,000th of a volt; Abbreviated as mV.

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyUnit.PartsPerMillion
member.summary: Imperial system unit of measure for the concentration of a substance; Abbreviated as ppm.

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyUnit.GramsPerLiter
member.summary: Metric system unit of measure for the concentration of a substance; Abbreviated as g/L.

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyUnit.pH
member.summary: pH Level (used to measure acidity in a water-based solution).

member.name: T:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyRenderHint
member.summary: Defines hints for user interfaces as to the intended usage of a device property; Specified by the interface property .

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyRenderHint.None
member.summary: Indicates the property value should be displayed using normal editing controls, such as a check box for booleans, a text box for string, etc...

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyRenderHint.OnOff
member.summary:
Indicates the property is intended to be displayed as on/off switch.
Only valid for properties whose type is .

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyRenderHint.OnOffValues
member.summary:
Indicates the property is an additional value that can be set, in addition to an associated property whose render hint is .
In other words, there will be 2 properties. One will be the property that turns on/off the device feature. The other will be the one that configures that device feature.
For example, turning on a strobe light may offer a preset list of flashing patterns to choose from. The intention here is that a user interface might want to show the 2 properties closely coupled together. This propertys will be populated.

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyRenderHint.SetpointTarget
member.summary: Indicates the property is intended to be displayed as range of values the user can target, for example, as a slider or a numeric spinner.

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyRenderHint.SetpointActual
member.summary: Indicates the property is intended to be displayed as the actual/current value when there is another property with the hint of .

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyRenderHint.Slider
member.summary:
Indicates the property is intended to be displayed as slider or similar control.
How exactly the slider is rendered can vary depending on the number of values specified by the range and and the between them.
The should also be factored in when rendering the slider.
If the is populated, it indicates custom labels from the device for each value (e.g. Slow, Medium, Fast).

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyRenderHint.Status
member.summary:
Indicates the property is the status of an associated property.
For example, turning on a pump may require a "priming" phase. One property would exist to turn the pump on/off. In order to define the "priming" status of the 1st property, a 2nd property would exist with this render hint. Finally, the 2nd property would have its set to the of the 1st property.
The intention here is that a user interface might want to show the 2 properties closely coupled together since one is the status of the other.

member.name: T:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyStates
member.summary: Defines state information about a device property; Specified by the interface property .

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyStates.Default
member.summary: Indicates a default, valid state.

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyStates.Disabled
member.summary:
Indicates if the property is currently disabled.
This may change based on the values of other properties. For example, changing the value of one property may disable another property.

member.name: F:ProgrammingDataGenerator.DeviceProperties.DevicePropertyStates.ValueNotAvailable
member.summary:
Indicates if the value of the property is not currently available.
In other words, the device may not have the value yet or the device is not capable of retrieving the value (for example, if a temperature sensor is not connected).
When this flag is present, the value returned by or must be ignored.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.DeviceTypes.RADAVReceiver.Feedback.SupportsUnsolicitedFeedback
member.summary: Lets a driver define if the API supports providing updates without polling. If this is enabled, then the driver's polling sequence will only be sent until each individual poll command receives a response. The driver will poll again like this if the connection state goes from false to true.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.DeviceTypes.BlurayPlayer.Feedback.SupportsUnsolicitedFeedback
member.summary: Lets a driver define if the API supports providing updates without polling. If this is enabled, then the driver's polling sequence will only be sent until each individual poll command receives a response. The driver will poll again like this if the connection state goes from false to true.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.DeviceTypes.CableBox.Feedback.SupportsUnsolicitedFeedback
member.summary: Lets a driver define if the API supports providing updates without polling. If this is enabled, then the driver's polling sequence will only be sent until each individual poll command receives a response. The driver will poll again like this if the connection state goes from false to true.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.DeviceTypes.Display.Feedback.SupportsUnsolicitedFeedback
member.summary: Lets a driver define if the API supports providing updates without polling. If this is enabled, then the driver's polling sequence will only be sent until each individual poll command receives a response. The driver will poll again like this if the connection state goes from false to true.

member.name: P:Crestron.RAD.DeviceTypes.VideoServer.Feedback.SupportsUnsolicitedFeedback
member.summary: Lets a driver define if the API supports providing updates without polling. If this is enabled, then the driver's polling sequence will only be sent until each individual poll command receives a response. The driver will poll again like this if the connection state goes from false to true.

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.IDeviceCapability

member.summary: Describes an device which has capabilites that can be queried.

member.summary: Queries for a capability of the device
member.typeparam: The capability to retrieve
member.returns: An object implementing the capability, or null if the capability is not supported.
